fn.p: Lorenzo Corsini is a research fellow at Department of Economics, University of Pisa where he also received his PhD. Most of his research is on labor economics, covering both theoretical and empirical aspects. His areas of focus are welfare systems and institutions in the labor markets and their effects on unemployment, wages, and income distribution.

Pier Mario Pacini is a professor of economics at Department of Economics, University of Pisa. His main research areas are general equilibrium theory with focus on the problems of survival constraints and equilibrium selection, complex economic dynamics, and the economics of heterogeneous interacting agents.

Luca Spataro is an associate professor at Department of Economics, University of Pisa and is a fellow of CHILD, Turin. He received his PhD in Economics from the Sant’Anna School of Advanced Studies and has been Visiting Scholar at UCL, London, and visiting professor at University of Durham, UK. His main research topics are on optimal design of modern welfare states, pension funds, optimal taxation, and population economics. He has published several articles on international economic journals.

abstract.p: The authors provide a theoretical framework to model the workers' choice problem of opting among different pension schemes, a choice problem that is common to several countries that have reformed their social security system in the last decades. This process is currently affecting private sector employees in Italy, in particular after the second pillar reform in 2007. The authors argue that workers not only have to weigh out the pros and cons that different schemes offer but that they also must consider the effect that their choice exerts on the financial structure of the firm in which they work. Once the authors have formalized this decision problem, they study analytically the properties of the adhesion process, and then carry out some simulations to replicate the Italian evidence and to shed light on the outcomes of the Italian reform.

body.p: In the last twenty years, changes in the demographic structure and in the growth expectations have induced many countries to reform their Social Security System (SSS). One of the most common features of these reforms is the shift from a defined benefit (DB) scheme to a defined contribution (DC) scheme. According to the DB scheme, pensions mostly depend on past wages, length of service, and possibly expected length of the retirement period; according to the DC scheme, they depend on the contributions paid, the performance of pension funds (PF) where contributions are invested, and the length of the retirement period. Some countries have also introduced notional contribution schemes (NDC) where the pensions are financed through a Pay-As-You-Go (PAYG) scheme and are computed out of contributions paid, which are revalued at a given rate depending on some macroeconomic variables. While DB schemes are still common, new reforms introduced DC or NDC in several countries in the Organisation of Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD); in particular, Australia, Hungary, Mexico, and Slovak Republic have switched to some form of DC scheme, while Italy, Poland, and Sweden have introduced NDC schemes. Similar reforms were also implemented in South America, with DC schemes replacing DB schemes. Chile was the first one in 1981, and ten more countries followed in the late nineties. Depending on the country, these switches to the new schemes were partial or complete, and voluntary or mandatory (Whiteford and Whitehouse 2006; Mesa-Lago 2006). To all extents, many workers in these countries had the possibility to opt for complementary social security (CSS) investing thus in a PF, either as a substitute or a complement of the publicly granted pension.

The situation in Italy is not an exception. Here the SSS will hardly be able to grant adequate pension benefits to the current generations of young workers, in particular temporary workers, and after the 1990s reforms that transformed the PAYG Italian SSS from a DB to a NDC scheme, the replacement rate between pension and last wage of private sector employees will decrease from current 70 to 80 percent to less favorable levels ranging between 55 and 79 percent, depending on both the working career length and the retirement age (Spataro 2009). In order to cope with this issue, since the first reform of SSS in 1993, several laws have been introduced to strengthen the CSS, which has remained undersized, both in absolute terms and compared to the rest of developed countries.

Given the relatively poor results of previous attempts, a reform was conceived in 2004 and implemented in 2007 in order to boost the second pillar for private sector employees. This reform affected the preexisting termination indemnity payments (Trattamento di Fine Rapporto [TFR]) scheme, according to which a part of workers' wage is withheld by the employer and given back, revaluated at a certain rate upon retirement or upon job termination. In many respects, the TFR resembles a mandatory DB scheme (although the benefit is paid as a lump sum at the end of career), with contributions withheld and managed directly by the employer. The 2007 reform revised the mandatory nature of this scheme and allowed workers to invest the contributions to the TFR in the “second pillar” system through the principle of silent or implied consent and the provision of substantial fiscal incentives. The switch from TFR to CSS is irreversible, while the choice of remaining at the TFR scheme can be reconsidered at any time (see The Institutional Framework in Italy after the Recent Reforms section for a deeper description of the reform).

However, two years after the introduction of this reform, the observed adhesion rates to CSS remain astonishingly low, at only 26 percent of potential private sector subscribers by the end of 2008 according to official data. These low figures may be due to transitory causes, given the recent negative performances of financial markets; they may also rest, as has been argued by Boeri and Zingales (2008), on structural characteristics of Italian workers, such as risk aversion, lack of information or of appropriate financial literacy, and scarce trust in financial institutions. Since we believe that such elements are important in explaining the outcome of the reform under investigation, in the present work we try to take them properly into account. However, in our opinion, there might be other causes at work that have been somehow overlooked so far. More precisely our argument rests on the observation of a stylized fact concerning the pattern of adhesions to the second pillar in Italy; that is, adhesion rates are positively correlated with firms' size. This correlation may partly be due to different rules for firms above or below 50 employees (see The Institutional Framework in Italy after the Recent Reforms section), but even within these two class sizes the same correlation between adhesion and firm dimension is present. To some extent then, there appears to be a mechanism that links adhesion to the second pillar to firms' size. It is this issue that we examine. This is particularly relevant if we consider that about 54 percent of the Italian labor force is employed in firms with less than 50 workers so that, if such a feature of adhesions is going to persist, a large part of the labor force will probably not switch to the newly introduced scheme, thus casting doubts on the long-run effectiveness of the reform.

The Italian 2007 reform has been analyzed by some authors, but a full assessment is still to be done.1 In fact, those other analyses, although effective in highlighting some aspects of the problem, have not provided a general model capable of rationalizing at the same time the aggregate outcomes of the reform and, in particular, the relationship between firm size and adhesion rates to PF.

In this article, we start from the above-mentioned empirical evidence, and we provide a possible explanation by modeling explicitly the decision process behind workers' choice, bringing to light the determinants of the choice to opt for a new pension scheme. This decision process has not been studied in detail in the literature, even if some empirical analyses on partly similar issues exist. For example, Urrutia, Mitchell, and Todd (2008) try to assess the determinants of the choice between different private PF in Chile, stressing the role of financial literacy, and Butler and Teppa (2007) investigate the determinants behind the individual decisions to annuitize or to cash out accumulated pension capital in Switzerland.2

Indeed, the problem we analyze is in part a classic case of choice under uncertainty, but it is further complicated by two aspects that are peculiar to the situation at hand: the choice to switch from TFR to PF is an irreversible one, and the decision has potentially relevant consequences also for the firms. The latter is particularly important as the availability of the TFR stock might have both negative and positive effects on firms: it generates a sort of firing cost similar to a severance payment (in fact a fired worker takes away from the firm the amount he has invested; see Garibaldi and Pacelli 2008 for an analysis of this aspect), but it also supplies a source of credit and liquidity should the need arise. Hence, the decision of workers is a complex one, as they realize that their (irreversible) choice of adhering to an external PF affects their future career also through the cost–benefit they induce on the firms in which they are currently (and will be) employed.

As for the positive effects of keeping this stock inside the firm, the literature is still embryonic, with some partial exceptions. Bulow (1982) discusses workers' and firms' incentives for the creation of a corporate pension plan and tries to assess whether this can be seen as a form of implicit contract; Rauh (2006) analyzes the effect of a corporate PF on the internal financial resources and on the core business investments; and Rauh (2009) focuses on how a corporate PF might influence the financial investment strategy of firms. However, these articles are not interested in and do not introduce the irreversible choice problem of workers, and they also do not consider the role of worker investment inside the firm as a source of credit and liquidity, something that is central in our article.

We model the decision problem that workers face, having to choose once and for all between a safe (the TFR) and a risky (the PF) asset. The key point of our work is that, upon taking this decision, the agent will trade off not only the advantages and disadvantages of higher but riskier returns provided by CSS relative to TFR but also the “external effects” of his decision on the financial health of the firm in which he is employed. Indeed, in our model firms can, in case of need, finance themselves through three different channels: the TFR stock (if any) available inside the firm, the share of (or the very entrepreneurs') capital, and the credit market. Given that we assume some imperfections in the capital market and frictions in the labor market, the choice of an individual to switch from TFR to CSS induces damage to the financial solidity of the firm and, thus, a higher risk of unemployment. Moreover, such an external effect will turn out to be higher, the lower the number of workers employed by the firm, and so will be almost negligible for workers employed in large firms. Hence, the size of firms plays a crucial role in the worker decision.

The work is organized as follows: in Basic Model section, we lay out the baseline theoretical framework in order to determine the economic incentives according to which individuals decide whether to adhere or not to CSS, and we extend the analysis to the aggregate level, analyzing the adhesion rates to CSS stemming from individual choices. Next, in An Application to the Italian Case: The TFR Reform section, after sketching the institutional setting of the Italian CSS system and the 2007 reform, we complicate the analysis and simulate our model to replicate the main features of the Italian experience and to provide insights on its future outcomes and is followed by our conclusions.

sec.title: Basic Model
sec.p:
We imagine an economy populated by firms and individuals. All firms employ the same number of workers N (N will be taken as a measure of the size of the firm), and use the same technology for the production of a commodity Y (the numeraire) in a regime of perfect long-run competition. To do that, firms hire workers and pay them a gross wage w. Furthermore they pay out dividends to the owners of the capital stock available within the firm; the remuneration rate of capital is

In the end, there can be three possible final outcomes: no workers switch, only the least risk adverse workers switch, and all workers switch.

This analysis shows that the final outcome of our model displays a variety of possible values, values that are determined by the shape of the incentive function, by the partition of the population in terms of risk aversion, and by the starting conditions. Two final comments are worth making. First, we have treated here heterogeneity through the partition of population in two groups; however, it is possible to assume a partition in a larger number of groups and still derive the formal properties, obtaining then an increasing number of possible resting states. Second, we could have chosen other forms of heterogeneity in workers' characteristics (discount rate for example) or even in firms' characteristic (e.g., size); as long as our model can determine formally the effect of those characteristics on the incentive, this would produce similar analyses and conclusions. In any case, the formal treatment of more numerous partitions or different forms of heterogeneity, while not particularly complicated, would be extremely long. For these reasons, when treating more numerous groups (or a continuum of individuals) and several forms of heterogeneity at the same time, it is more appropriate and simpler to determine the solution numerically. An example of this is contained in An Application to the Italian Case: The TFR Reform section.

sec.title: An Application to the Italian Case: The TFR Reform
The Institutional Framework in Italy after the Recent Reforms
sec.p: The Italian TFR is regulated by article 2120 of the Civil law Code (Codice civile), which states that each firm in the private sector has to put aside for each tenured worker 6.91 percent of gross salary per year. These contributions are capitalized at 1.5 percent per year plus 75 percent of the inflation rate; therefore the TFR fund so far has represented a cheap source of financing for the firms. Employees have the possibility to partially withdraw from such a fund, although under very specific conditions (e.g., to purchase a house or for medical expenditures). Upon his or her dismissal, a worker has the right to obtain the whole TFR stock.12

In order to promote supplementary pensions, in 2007, a reform was introduced for private sector employees, which entails the possibility of devolving the TFR to the CSS. The adhesion to CSS is irreversible, and it may occur through a mechanism of silent or implied consent. To make the switch from TFR to CSS more attractive to workers, a particularly favorable fiscal treatment for the latter scheme has been conceived: the cumulated value of the investment obtained upon dismissal is taxed at a rate that ranges between 9 and 15 percent (depending on years of contributions), whereas in the case of TFR it is taxed at the average of last five years’ tax rate on personal income (usually around 23 percent but more for richer workers). Finally, the law explicitly allows for the possibility of receiving extra “employer contribution” for the workers switching to the CSS, provided that they add a voluntary contribution (currently these contributions amount to 1.16 and 1.27 percent of gross wage, respectively) and that they opt for occupational PF. As far as firms are concerned, to partially offset the potential damage to the financial solidity of enterprises, the legislation has provided tax rebates for contributions transferred to CSS. The reform also discriminates between firms of different sizes; workers employed in firms with more than fifty employees have to transfer their TFR to a publicly managed fund if they decide not to subscribe a PF.

The principle of “freedom of choice” explicitly stated by the law has been safeguarded through the mechanism of silent or implied consent. However, while the choice of switching to PF is irreversible, the option of maintaining contributions inside the firm can be reconsidered in any future period.

The outcome of the reform, in term of adhesion rates, is, after two years, unsatisfactory. As shown by Table 1 (panel A), from 2006 to 2007 the rate of subscription to CSS has increased from 16.28 percent to 25.11 percent and remained nearly stable in 2008. The situation is even worse if we consider that these data refer to workers that have adhered to any kind of PF. If we focus only on workers that transferred their TFR to CSS and if we exclude those that had adhered to a PF before 1993, we obtain lower figures (see Table 1 [panel B]). The latter data are probably more suitable to describe the outcome of the 2007 reform, which aimed at favoring the switch from TFR to CSS; hence, we refer to these data in the rest of the article. A second feature worth mentioning is that the adhesion rates are increasing with the size of the firm, as shown in Table 2 . In particular, Table 2 shows how total adhesions are distributed among firms of different size, and reveals that the distribution of adhesions and employment are significantly different. Consequently, adhesion rates vary greatly across size, with larger firms having higher rates. In the rest of the article, we try to shed light on these features of the 2007 reform.

sec.title: Simulation Strategy
sec.p: The model in Basic Model section sheds some light on the behavior of agents and the characteristics of the incentives they face when contemplating the switch to the new F scheme (see proposition 2). However, if we want to use it to replicate real data, we need to add more heterogeneity both among workers (in terms of preferences) and among firms (in terms of size and financial structure). Once we allow for heterogeneity of firms, agents have to form expectations on the possibility, when fired by a firm, to be hired in a firm that differs from the current one.

To deal with these aspects, we set up a simulation model. More precisely, we adopt a standard Agent Based Model approach. In what follows, we give a brief explanation of the mechanics of simulation; full details can be found in the extended version of this article (Corsini, Pacini, and Spataro 2010). Since the reform affected firms with more than fifty employees in a completely different way, we perform the simulation only for firms below that threshold, which are, however, the larger part of Italian firms, about 99 percent.

sec.title: The Mechanics of Simulation
sec.p:
The simulation of the model works according to a simple mechanic. Initially, each worker is generated drawing his specific parameters from a given distribution and is then assigned to a firm whose parameters have been randomly drawn as well. Then in any given period (t = 0,1,2,…) we compute the value of the incentive function for every worker, and according to that value we determine whether he switches to F or not. However, a worker with a positive incentive will actually switch only with a probability
α i
; by this we mean that there are some frictions in the process of switching due to misinformation, lack of financial literacy, or a sort of aversion to changing, with the parameter α measuring these frictions.13

Once the actual number of switches has been determined, a new period begins, in which a new s is determined in each firm according to what happened in the previous period and new values of the incentives are computed. This procedure goes on for several periods until the incentives of all workers are nonpositive or the adhesion rate is 1. At that point, equilibrium is reached, and the value of s becomes stable. In this process, workers have to form expectations on the possible firms where they may end up in case of dismissal and rehiring: in doing this, we imagine that they have perfect knowledge of the distribution of firms in terms of size and financial characteristics, so that they can formulate a distribution of probabilities on all the possible firms where they will end up working. In order for the simulations to be statistically significant, we perform them with a large number of firms and workers (4 million firms and roughly 12 million workers).

sec.title: The Setting of Base Parameters
sec.p: In order to assess the outcomes of our model for the Italian experience, we adopted the following empirical strategy: we set the parameters using existing data when available and resorting to proxies for all other variables, and we set the standard deviations of the parameters, when their value was not available, to one-third of their mean so that parameter variance does not produce economically unreasonable values.14 We also have to specify some further details, such as the tax regime and fiscal rebates, firms' contribution, and so on. Since these details were different before and after the reform, we are able to replicate both situations, and then investigate the effects of changes in terms of adhesion rate.
We briefly describe all the different parameters and the values that were assigned to them; for a detailed description, see Corsini, Pacini, and Spataro (2010).

sec.p: System parameters describe the economic system and therefore are common across all firms and workers. These parameters determine aspects of the labor market (the hiring rate and the replacement rate), of the credit markets (rate of return of firm’s capital and interest rate on consumer credit), and of the working of the F scheme (the contribution share over gross wage, the tax rate on contributions and on interests, the real returns in the F and T schemes).17 All values used in the simulation are summarized in Table 5 .

sec.title: Simulation Results
sec.p: Two features are worth mentioning. First, as it is clear from Figure 3 , the simulated participation rates neither stay at their starting level (0 at the beginning of the prereform period) nor reach 1, but lie somewhere in between. Second, the equilibrium value of s is significantly dependent on the size of the firms, with bigger firms displaying higher values of the adhesion rates, thus reflecting the empirical evidence for Italy.

caption.p: Our simulations of adhesion rates before and after the reform Note: PF = pension funds.

sec.p: Table 6 summarizes the results of the simulation, and shows that they are quite in line with the observed values of the adhesion rates, both for pre and postreform periods.
Hence, we can conclude that our model, in the baseline specification, is able to replicate the main features of the Italian experience concerning the reform of the second pillar.

As for the sensitivity analysis, we report in Figure 4 the cases concerning some crucial variables. The figure shows that, as predicted from our theoretical model, expected returns and risk aversion are particularly important in determining the choice, but small changes in their baseline values do not overthrow our results, so that our simulation appears to be stable. Also the sign of the effect of volatility is in line with our model prediction, but its magnitude is not particularly relevant.

caption.p: Sensitivity analysis Note: PF = pension funds.

sec.p: We now turn to some simulations in order to provide a picture of possible long-run outcomes of the reform. In particular, by exploring different scenarios concerning the economic performances of the PF scheme and of information, we aim at assessing whether the current scarce results of the 2007 reform are temporary (and due to the financial crisis) or permanent. More precisely we allow for different PF nominal returns and levels of α, and we extend the simulation periods from two to fifteen iterations, so that the reform has enough time to display its full effects. Figure 5a shows the results of such an exercise for the returns to PF investments for different firms' size. The results of this analysis show that the adhesion rate is indeed significantly sensitive to the returns of PF, but only when the latter are well above 5 percent do we observe a relevant value of the adhesion rate. This result seems to indicate that, other things being equal, the current outcomes are rather stable, and even once the financial crisis effects are fully over, the increase in the adhesion rates in firms of small–medium sizes will be small. Somehow more optimistic, although still unsatisfactory, is the picture that we obtain when higher PF returns are combined with higher degree of information (Figure 5b). This figure shows that, when real interest rates from the second pillar are the ones we observe before the financial crisis and when that information is fully spread throughout the labor force, then adhesion rates would increase of around 2 percent.

caption.p: Long-run outcomes for different expected returns of pension funds (PF) and degree of information

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this work, we build a model representing the decision process of workers when choosing between different pension schemes, and we use it to provide an additional possible explanation of the results of the Italian 2007 reform of CSS for private sector employees. We aim at providing a possible explanation to the observed positive correlation between adhesion rates and firms' size. More precisely, in our model, each worker when deciding whether to permanently adhere or not to the second pillar not only has to trade off the direct economic advantages and disadvantages (consisting in higher but riskier returns) but also has to take into account the effects of this individual decision on the financial health of the firm in which he is employed. In fact, the more workers switch to a pension fund, the more they indirectly induce the risk of default of the firm in which they work, since they erode a source of internal financing in the presence of imperfect financial markets. However, the higher the number of workers employed in a firm, the lower will be the effect of the individual decision to switch to a pension fund on the financial health of the firm.

Clearly, the final decision on which scheme to adopt must trade off returns and risks and both the individuals' and aggregate outcomes will depend on three factors: financial incentives provided by the second pillar, firms' technological and financial conditions, and personal attitudes toward risk and information.

We worked out this framework both theoretically and through simulations. On the theoretical side, the main conclusions are that workers' incentives to switch to PF depend negatively on risk aversion and positively on the expected returns of the PF and on the size of the firms. The financial structure of firm and the share of workers that already switched to the second pillar are also relevant in determining the size of the incentive, with the latter variable (the share of workers already switched) pointing to the presence of a sort of net externality. As for the equilibrium rate, we show that it is crucially dependent on the shape of the incentive function and on the partition of the population in terms of risk aversion.

Through simulations of the Italian case we examined the aggregate outcomes stemming from individual decisions, taking explicitly into account the heterogeneity of firms' and agents' characteristics and allowing also for more general assumptions on the distribution of productivity shocks. Our results show that there is a positive significant relation between the rate of subscription to the PF scheme and the size of the firm in which agents are employed, thus confirming the empirical evidence whereby we observe higher subscription rates in firms of larger size. The sensitivity analysis shows that adhesion rates are also sensitive to returns from the PF and to the degree of risk aversion. Moreover, more optimistic scenarios on the returns from PF do not seem to overthrow the results, so that the expected adhesion rates among workers of small and medium firms in the regime phase of the reform will not be significantly higher than the ones we currently observe.

Summing up, our results seem to grasp some new features of the Italian experience, which, together with the already existing explanations (such as workers' lack of financial literacy and scarce trust in the financial markets) are responsible for the unsatisfactory results of the reform so far. In particular, we argue that other economic explanations of such outcomes may be represented by the peculiarity of the Italian production system, populated by a large number of small and medium enterprises, which are characterized by a fragile financial structure and which also entail a stronger relationship between employers and employees, such that the option of maintaining the TFR inside the firm and investing some money in it appears to workers as an insurance against future unemployment. Other explanations are the institutional characteristics of the Italian labor and financial market and workers' preferences (risk aversion), opportunities, and information sets. On policy grounds, our results show that more satisfactory results in terms of adhesion rates could be achieved by allowing for higher returns from the second pillar (which could be realized through stronger fiscal incentives to the adhesion to the second pillar), by appropriate information campaigns, and finally by conceiving policies that make the transition experience of unemployment less traumatic for workers.

Although our model allows us to deal with this case, the solution it produces is trivial: in fact, should the F scheme entail lower expected rate of returns it would never be chosen by risk adverse employees as it also displays volatility and produces an increase in the probability of becoming unemployed.

The parameter B is important because it also captures to what extent the level of contributions paid during unemployment affect the choice of the scheme. In fact, differences in the contribution rate during employment and unemployment affect consumption (as seen in note 6) eventually ending up in B. Thus, through B, we can assess how this aspect affects the value of I. In the particular case when contributions are not paid at all during unemployment spells we have B = 0.

It depends also on other factors such as the fiscal regime, fiscal rebates, possible additional contributions from firms, and the age of retiring, all of which we account for in the simulation.

For the values of parameters (α) we used proxies taken from surveys about workers' knowledge and aims on pensions: in particular, for the prereform period we used a 2002 survey by Bank of Italy in which 50 percent of workers were unable to predict what their future pension would be; as for the postreform period, we relied on ISAE (2005), which shows that, at the end of 2005, 71 percent of workers were informed about the upcoming TFR reform. The values for the parameters of h and k were derived from Bardazzi and Pazienza (2005) and Ministry of Labour and Social Policies (2002), respectively.

Clearly, the values of expected returns in the F scheme are a key aspect. For the simulation of the prereform, we used historical data and adopted the average rate of return of PF over the years 1999–2006, as given in Cesari, Grande, and Panetta (2007). Things are more complex for the postreform period: a long enough time series is not available, and the 2008 financial crisis is likely to have induced lower expectations on returns for F investments. Hence, we decided to modify the prereform expectations of the same amount of the reduction of the returns on long terms government bonds (ten years' BTP in our case) in the second part of 2008, using data from Bank of Italy.
